descriptions: Student is unable to tell time to the nearest five minutes on either analog or digital clocks.
Student can tell time to the nearest hour on digital clocks, but struggles with analog clocks and finer increments.
Student can tell time to the nearest 15 minutes on digital and analog clocks with some errors.
Student can accurately tell time to the nearest five minutes on digital clocks and generally on analog clocks, with occasional minor errors.
Student can accurately tell time to the nearest five minutes on both analog and digital clocks consistently.
Student can accurately and quickly tell time to the nearest five minutes on both analog and digital clocks and explain the relationship between the two formats.
Student does not understand or incorrectly uses a.m. and p.m.
Student shows limited understanding of a.m. and p.m. and struggles to apply them correctly.
Student sometimes uses a.m. and p.m. correctly, but makes frequent errors.
Student generally uses a.m. and p.m. correctly, but occasionally makes errors in context.
Student consistently uses a.m. and p.m. correctly in various contexts.
Student demonstrates a thorough understanding of a.m. and p.m. and can explain their usage accurately in different scenarios.
Student shows no understanding of time relationships (minutes in an hour, days in a month, weeks in a year).
Student knows only one time relationship (e.g., minutes in an hour) but struggles with others.
Student knows two time relationships but struggles with the others.
Student knows most time relationships but makes occasional errors.
Student knows all listed time relationships accurately.
Student demonstrates a deep understanding of all listed time relationships and can apply them to solve complex problems.
